objenome.op

Class Node<X extends Node,Y>

  • java.lang.Object
    • objenome.op.Node<X,Y>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Cloneable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ArcCosecant, ArcCosine, ArcCotangent, ArcSecant, ArcSine, ArcTangent, AreaHyperbolicCosine, AreaHyperbolicSine, AreaHyperbolicTangent, BooleanNode, CoefficientPower, Cosecant, Cotangent, Factorial, GreaterThan, HyperbolicCosine, HyperbolicSine, If, IfAndOnlyIf, Implies, InvertProtected, LessThan, Literal, MathNode, Max, Min3, ModuloProtected, Nand, Nor, Secant, SeqN, Signum, VariableNode, Void, Xor

    public abstract class Node<X extends Node,Y>
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable
    A Node is a vertex in a tree structure which represents a program. A node can be thought of as an expression in a computer programming language. Evaluating a node will involve evaluating any children and optionally returning a value. Subclasses of Node should ensure they call the superclass constructor with all child nodes so information such as the arity of the node can be maintained. Concrete subclasses must also implement evaluate() to evaluate the expression represented by the tree. Nodes which support mixed type arguments, or terminal nodes with no arguments must also override the getReturnType(Class<?>) method to indicate their return type. The clone and newInstance methods are also heavily used, so implementations should ensure this classes implementations are sufficient or override as necessary.
    Since:
    2.0

    • Constructor Detail

      • Node

        @SafeVarargs
public Node(X... children)
        Constructs a new Node with the given child nodes. The arity of the node will be the number of child nodes provided. The child nodes may be initially set here as null and replaced before evaluation. Terminal nodes are simply nodes with no children.
        Parameters:
        children - child nodes to this node

    • Method Detail

      • evaluate

        public abstract Y evaluate()
        Subclasses should implement this method to perform some operation with respect to its children and return a result. If there is no result (for example, because this node has a Void data-type), then null should be returned.
        Returns:
        the result of evaluating the node tree rooted at this node

        Returns a specific child by index
        Parameters:
        index - the index of the child to be returned, valid indexes run from 0 to getArity()-1
        Returns:
        the child node at the specified index

        public Node getParent()

        Returns:
        the node that this node is a child of

      • getChildren

        public X[] getChildren()
        Returns an array of this node's children. Modifying this array will not change the set of children, but modifying the nodes will alter the nodes of the tree.
        Returns:
        an array of this node's children

      • getInputs

        public final X[] getInputs()
        alias for getChildren()

      • setChildren

        @SafeVarargs
public final void setChildren(X... children)
        Sets the child nodes of this node. Modifications to this array after being set will not modify the set of child nodes. The number of children set here does not need to match the current arity.
        Parameters:
        children - the nodes to set as children in order

      • getNode

        public Node getNode(int n)
        Returns the element at the specified position in the node tree, where this node is considered to be the root - that is the 0th node. The tree is traversed in pre-order (depth first).
        Parameters:
        n - the index of the node to be returned
        Returns:
        the node at the specified position in this node tree
        Throws:
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if n is out of range

      • setNode

        public Node setNode(int n,
                    Node newNode)
        Replaces the node at the specified position in this node tree, where this node is considered to be the root node - that is, the 0th node. The tree is traversed in pre-order (depth first). It is not possible to set the 0th node, since it does not make sense for an object to be able to replace itself.
        Parameters:
        n - the index of the node to replace
        newNode - the node to be stored at the specified position
        Throws:
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if n is out of range

      • nthNonTerminalIndex

        public int nthNonTerminalIndex(int n)
        Returns the index of the nth non-terminal node, where this node is considered to be the root - that is the 0th node. The tree's nodes are counted in pre-order (depth first) to locate the nth function, and return its index within all nodes. Will throw an exception if the index is out of bounds, which will be the case for all indexes when called on a terminal node.
        Parameters:
        n - the non-terminal to find the index of
        Returns:
        the index of the nth non-terminal node
        Throws:
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if n is out of range

      • nthTerminalIndex

        public int nthTerminalIndex(int n)
        Returns the index of the nth terminal node, where this node is considered to be the root - that is the 0th node. The tree's nodes are counted in pre-order (depth first) to locate the nth terminal, and return its index within all nodes.
        Parameters:
        n - the terminal to find the index of
        Returns:
        the index of the nth terminal node
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if n is out of bounds

      • nodesAtDepth

        public java.util.Collection<Node> nodesAtDepth(int depth)
        Retrieves all the nodes in the node tree at a specified depth from this current node. This node is considered to be at depth zero.
        Parameters:
        depth - the specified depth of the nodes to return
        Returns:
        a List of all the nodes at the specified depth

      • getArity

        public int getArity()
        Returns the number of immediate children this Node has. This is effectively the number of inputs the node has. A node with arity zero, is considered to be a terminal node.
        Returns:
        the number of children required by this node

      • getIdentifier

        public abstract java.lang.String getIdentifier()
        Should be implemented to return an indentifier for this node. For functions, where this is effectively the function name, this would normally be unique within the given problem.
        Returns:
        a String identifier for this node.

      • dataType

        public final java.lang.Class<?> dataType()
        Returns the data-type of this node based on the child nodes that are currently set. If any of this node's child nodes are currently null, or their data-types are invalid, then the return type will also be null.
        Returns:
        the return type of this node or null if any of its children remain unset or are of an invalid data-type

      • dataType

        public java.lang.Class dataType(java.lang.Class... inputTypes)
        Returns this node's return type given the provided input data-types. The default implementation for a non-terminal is that the node will support the closure requirement - the return type will be the widest of the input types, or null if they are not compatible. The default return value for a terminal is Void. Mixed type non-terminal nodes and most terminal nodes should override this method. If the input types are invalid then null should be returned.
        Parameters:
        inputTypes - the set of input data-types for which to get the return type.
        Returns:
        the return type of this node given the provided input types, or null if the set of input types is invalid.

      • isNonTerminal

        public boolean isNonTerminal()
        Returns true if this node has an arity of greater than 0.
        Returns:
        true if this node is a non-terminal, and false otherwise.

      • isTerminal

        public boolean isTerminal()
        Returns true if this node has an arity of 0
        Returns:
        true if this node is a terminal, and false otherwise

        public int hashCode()

      • clone

        public Node clone()
        Creates a deep copy of this node and its node tree. Each child node will be cloned. Use this method for copying a whole node tree. Some implementations of this class may need to override this method.
        Overrides:
        clone in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        a copy of this Node and its children

      • newInstance

        public Node newInstance()
        Constructs a new instance of this node-type. Rather than copying the node tree, this node is copied without children. In the case of many terminal nodes the bahaviour of this method will be the same as the clone method. By default this method will simply return a new instance of the same type in the same manner as clone, but with all children removed. Note that there is no requirement for an implementation to return a different instance.
        Returns:
        a copy of this Node with all children removed

      • newInstance

        public Node newInstance(Node[] newChildren)

      • equals

        public boolean equals(java.lang.Object obj)
        Compares an this node to another object for equality. Two nodes may be considered equal if they have equal arity, equal identifiers, and their children are also equal (and in the same order). Some nodes may wish to enforce a stricter contract.
        Overrides:
        equals in class java.lang.Object
        Parameters:
        obj -
        Returns:

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Returns a string representation of this node. The default implementation is output of the form: 
         identifier(children)
        where identifier is the node's identifier as returned by getIdentifier, and children is a space separated list of child nodes, according to their toString representation.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        a string representation of this node and its children

        public boolean allConstDescendants()

      • normalize

        public Node normalize()
        allows a node to apply reduction or simplification after is has been created. by default returns itself

      • asDouble

        public double asDouble()
